title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #1125**

If f : ℝ → ℝ satisfies 2f(x) ≤ f(x+h) + f(x+2h) for all x and h > 0, must f be monotonic?

**Status:** SOLVED (Laczkovich 1984)

Erdős wrote "if it were my problem I would offer $500 for it."
mathContext: A functional inequality problem connecting one-sided convexity to monotonicity.

title: Kemperman Inequality
content:
**satisfiesKemperman f:**

∀x ∈ ℝ, ∀h > 0: 2f(x) ≤ f(x+h) + f(x+2h)

This is a one-sided discrete convexity condition.

title: Alternative Formulation
content:
**satisfiesKempermanAlt f:**

f(x) - f(x+h) ≤ f(x+h) - f(x+2h)

The "jump down" from x to x+h is bounded by the "jump up" from x+h to x+2h.

title: Equivalence
content:
**kemperman_equiv:**

The two formulations are algebraically equivalent.

2f(x) ≤ f(x+h) + f(x+2h) ↔ f(x) - f(x+h) ≤ f(x+h) - f(x+2h)

title: Non-Decreasing
content:
**isNonDecreasing f:**

∀x ≤ y: f(x) ≤ f(y)

The function doesn't decrease as the argument increases.

title: Non-Increasing
content:
**isNonIncreasing f:**

∀x ≤ y: f(y) ≤ f(x)

The function doesn't increase as the argument increases.

title: Monotonic
content:
**isMonotonic f:**

isNonDecreasing f ∨ isNonIncreasing f

The function is either always going up or always going down.

title: The Main Question
content:
**kemperman_question:**

Does satisfiesKemperman(f) imply isMonotonic(f)?

This is what Erdős Problem #1125 asks.

title: Measurability
content:
**IsMeasurable f:**

f is Lebesgue measurable.

Measurable functions cannot be too pathological - they respect the measure structure of ℝ.
mathContext: Non-measurable functions require the Axiom of Choice to construct.

title: Kemperman's Theorem (1969)
content:
**kemperman_1969:**

If f satisfies Kemperman's inequality AND f is measurable, then f is monotonic.

This was the partial result before Laczkovich.
mathContext: Published in Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 1969.

title: Laczkovich's Theorem (1984)
content:
**laczkovich_1984:**

If f : ℝ → ℝ satisfies 2f(x) ≤ f(x+h) + f(x+2h) for all x and h > 0, then f is monotonic.

NO MEASURABILITY ASSUMPTION NEEDED.

This completely resolves Erdős Problem #1125.

title: Question Resolved
content:
**kemperman_question_resolved:**

Laczkovich's theorem directly implies the Kemperman question is TRUE.

The main result follows immediately from the axiom.

title: Interpretation
content:
**kemperman_interpretation:**

The inequality bounds how much f can "jump down" then "jump up":

f(x) - f(x+h) ≤ f(x+2h) - f(x+h)

This prevents certain oscillation patterns.
mathContext: The key insight is that this bounds local oscillations.

title: Constants Satisfy
content:
**constant_satisfies:**

Constant functions f(x) = c satisfy Kemperman's inequality.

Proof: 2c ≤ c + c = 2c. ✓

title: Linear Functions Satisfy
content:
**linear_satisfies:**

Linear functions f(x) = ax + b satisfy Kemperman's inequality.

Proof: 2(ax + b) = 2ax + 2b ≤ (a(x+h) + b) + (a(x+2h) + b) = 2ax + 3ah + 2b for h > 0.

title: x² Satisfies
content:
**square_satisfies:**

f(x) = x² satisfies Kemperman's inequality.

Proof: 2x² ≤ (x+h)² + (x+2h)² = 2x² + 6xh + 5h² for h > 0. ✓

title: Non-Measurable Context
content:
**non_measurable_context:**

Non-measurable functions can be very pathological. For example, there exist additive functions f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y) that are not linear.

Kemperman's inequality turns out to be strong enough to force monotonicity anyway.
mathContext: Such pathological functions require the Axiom of Choice.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_1125_summary:**

Kemperman's inequality implies monotonicity.

This combines all components into the main result.

title: Problem Solved
content:
**erdos_1125_solved:**

Erdős Problem #1125 was completely resolved by Laczkovich in 1984.
